summary: A letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the filing of a sealed reply memorandum in support of Maxwell's pretrial motions. The document outlines the procedure for submitting confidential information under seal for government review of potential redactions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm Cohen & Gresser, who is the defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: The attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who authored and signed the letter on behalf of client Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: Everdell is the attorney representing Maxwell in her criminal case, as indicated by the letter being written on her behalf.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell.

events.title: Filing of Sealed Reply Memorandum
events.description: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell informs the court they will file a sealed reply memorandum in support of her pretrial motions, containing confidential discovery information.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team was preparing an Omnibus Reply Memorandum in support of her pretrial motions related to the S2 Superseding Indictment.
The reply memorandum contained confidential information from discovery, requiring it to be filed under seal pursuant to a Protective Order.
The filing procedure involved submitting the document to the court and government by email for review and potential redaction before public filing.
